Award.AwardTitle: IGERT--Interdisciplinary Evolutionary Primatology: Conservation and Human Evolution join Behavior, Bones and Genes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports the further development of the New York Consortium in Evolutionary Primatology (NYCEP), a program that draws upon faculty and resources from five institutions in New York City: City University of New York, Columbia University, New York University, the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), and the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS). The program spans the integrative and interdisciplinary field of "evolutionary primatology," which applies methods and theories from a broad range of the natural sciences to the study of the biology and evolution of humans and other primates.

This renewal award allows NYCEP to amplify its training in conservation science and human evolution; implement a number of innovative curricular initiatives that ensure interdisciplinarity; restructure the training program to enable students to progress faster towards the Ph.D. and publish earlier; expand international research opportunities; develop new partnerships with programs in geological sciences at Rutgers, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia, and AMNH, genetics and human evolution at Max-Planck Institute/Leipzig and Universität Tübingen, and field behavior and conservation in South Africa, Kenya, Ecuador and Peru; extend its relationships with the Richard Gilder Graduate School at AMNH and in conservation science with WCS; develop novel approaches to recruit underrepresented groups; and enhance the NYCEP community by involving graduate students more extensively in NYCEP-wide activities. This innovative training program produces graduate students who are professionally and technically qualified to lead scientific research, education and public outreach in an increasingly socio-politically complex, interdisciplinary and global arena.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NYCEP (the New York Consortium in Evolutionary Primatology) is a multi-institutional graduate research and training program including PhD students and faculty from the City University of New York, Columbia University, New York University and the Richard Gilder Graduate School at the American Museum of Natural History, as well as staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society. NYCEP has been supported by NSF since 1991, the most recent funding being from the IGERT program between July 1, 2010, and December 31, 2017. NYCEP represents a rare combination of public and private universities together with privately endowed (and publicly assisted) institutions dedicated to education and bringing science to the public. NYCEP research and training focus on primate (including human) evolution, social behavior, ecology, conservation biology, genomics, population genetics, comparative morphology, paleontology and systematics.

Sixty-four NSF-funded trainees and 23 unfunded associates (and over 60 associated faculty) participated in NYCEP activities during the 2010-2017 time span of the award. Twenty-nine trainees received the PhD (5 of these entered in fall 2010 or afterward), along with 9 associates. There are 35 current trainees and 14 associates in the program. 75% of the trainees are female, and 9% are members of under-represented minority groups. Of the 14 associates, 12 are female, 6 international and 2 minority. These students were served pedagogically through a redesign of our core course package; updating of our innovative "Professional Development" course; and teaching a range of new and continuing team-taught interdisciplinary courses and specialty elective courses.

All IGERT students participate in an international field-based project, usually directed by a NYCEP faculty member or partner, typically during the first (or sometimes second) summer of the trainee's graduate career. Since 2010, IGERT students have undertaken paleontological field research in Kenya, Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Greece, Romania and Spain; and primate behavioral, ecological and genetic studies in Congo, Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar, Nigeria, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. Forty-five trainees worked in 25 countries (a total of 102 student-country visits) from 2010-2017.

NYCEP trainees have been outstanding in receipt of research grants from major providers and other awards. Eight have received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships (as well as three honorable mentions), while 18 (plus 7 associates) have been awarded NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grants (DDIGs). One trainee won the Judge's Choice award in the 2013 NSF IGERT Video and Poster competition. Six trainees received Dissertation Fieldwork grants from the Wenner Gren Foundation (the leading anthropology-wide funding source), while seven were awarded dissertation research grants from the Leakey Foundation (focusing on paleoanthropology and primate behavior/ecology). Four trainees received dissertation fellowships from the American Association of University Women, two won U.S. Student Fulbright Fellowships (to work in Madagascar and Zambia), one received a James F. Nacey Fellowship from the Nacey Maggioncalda Foundation, and one was awarded a Point Foundation Fellowship for LGBTQ Scholars. The American Association of Physical Anthropologists makes awards each year for the best student podium and poster presentations. NYCEP students received seven awards and four Honorable Mentions from 2014-2018.

Of the 29 trainees who received a NYCEP PhD since 2010, 11 hold tenure-track positions as Assistant Professor of Anthropology, Anatomy or Biology; two are in the American Museum of Natural History Education department, one in a senior, the other a junior position. Eight are postdocs and three are adjunct Assistant Professors; two hold appointments in writing programs, one is in industry and two others are seeking full-time jobs while teaching. NYCEP trainees, associates and faculty participated in 473 outreach activities and authored 1578 publications over the course of IGERT funding.
